Organizational titles for the Planning and Management Division were changed in CCDM 30.1.1.2.2, CCDM 30.1.1.2.3, CCDM 30.1.1.3.4.2 and CCDM 30.1.1.3.4.3 as a result of the reorganization of the office of the Associate Chief Counsel (Finance and Management), Planning and Finance Division.

) The mission of the Office of the Chief Counsel is to serve America’s fairly and with integrity by providing correct and impartial interpretation of the internal revenue laws and the highest quality legal advice and representation for the Internal Revenue Service. (

) This mission encompasses providing the correct legal interpretation of the internal revenue laws, representing the IRS in litigation, and providing all legal support needed by the IRS to carry out its mission of serving America’s taxpayers. In carrying out these responsibilities, Counsel must interpret the with complete impartiality so that the American public will have confidence the tax law is being applied with integrity and fairness. (
) The Chief Counsel Directives Manual (CCDM), published as Parts
of the Internal Revenue Manual, is the authoritative statement of policy guidance for the IRS Office of Chief Counsel on matters covered therein. (

) While some parts and sections of the CCDM may contain specific or processes, it is neither designed nor intended to be a comprehensive checklist or “how to” guide for every action or process. Step-by-step guides operating instructions may be developed outside of the CCDM, where appro- priate. The principal intent of the CCDM is to clearly and concisely reflect Counsel policy and guidance on critical functions for the effective operation the Chief Counsel organization. (

) In some cases, the Office of Chief Counsel follows IRS policy and such as for travel. For all Personnel Policy, since the Office of Chief Counsel IRS part of the Legal Division of the Department of the Treasury, our policies, guidance, and procedures may differ from those of the IRS. (

) Where the Office of Chief Counsel, as a matter of policy, has elected to an IRS policy, guidance, or procedure on a particular matter, then the section of the CCDM shall state that the Chief Counsel expressly adopts and incorporates that specific IRS policy, guidance, or procedure. For those sections, any change to IRS policy will automatically change Office of Chief Counsel policy. (

) Where an Office of Chief Counsel policy may be substantively the same as that for the IRS, but the Chief Counsel has elected not to expressly adopt incorporate IRS policy, the Chief Counsel policy in the CCDM will be stated without reference to the parallel IRS policy. For those sections, any change IRS policy will not affect Office of Chief Counsel policy on that particular matter, unless the Chief Counsel expressly decides to approve a change. (

) All Associate Chief Counsel and Division Counsel offices are responsible for ensuring that the CCDM reflects the current policies, guidance, and of the Office of Chief Counsel. Designated Associate Chief Counsel or Counsel offices are responsible for monitoring the currency of their assigned CCDM parts and ensuring that they are updated in a timely fashion. provisions of the CCDM affect many different organizations, the Part does not have exclusive control of all substantive elements of its assigned part. (05-28-2014) Maintenance of the CCDM
30.1 Office of Chief Counsel Mission
The CCDM Parts will be managed by the following organizations:

The Associate Chief Counsel (Finance and Management), through the Planning and Management Division, is responsible for the administrative oversight of the CCDM. This includes processing all changes provided by the issuing office for the CCDM, and ensuring that the current version of the CCDM is published in accordance with IRS policy. The Planning and Manage- ment Division will coordinate with the IRS Service-wide Policy Directives and Electronic Research (SPDER) and Media and Publications organizations and will issue procedures within the Office of Chief Counsel for publication of the CCDM. For detailed information, see CCDM
, Office of Chief Counsel Directives System.

The MSOP sets the general direction for the Office’s efforts while paralleling and supporting the Commissioner’s and Treasury’s strategic planning efforts.

) Secure Business Operations The strategic planning process serves as a framework for senior involvement and guidance. It also provides for greater integration between planning, budgeting, and performance accountability mechanisms. In addition to providing their own input and discussion into the MSOP, executives work closely with their IRS and Treasury colleagues to their ideas concerning their future direction and priorities. The Chief Counsel reviews accomplishment of the strategic priorities the IRS Business Performance Review (BPR) process. The Chief Counsel shares the status of priority accomplishment with the IRS Commissioner quarterly BPR meetings. The Planning and Management Division in the Office of Associate Chief Counsel (F&M) initiates strategic planning for the Office of Chief Counsel working with each Associate Chief Counsel or Division Counsel to develop MSOP based on the Commissioner’s Plan and new priorities. Office of Chief Counsel Mission (

) At the beginning of each fiscal year, each Associate Chief Counsel and Division Counsel develops an Executive Performance Agreement (EPA) that Chief Counsel translates the broad MSOP objectives into specific objectives for that year. Division Counsel Specific performance measures are coordinated between the Associate Measures Counsel or Division Counsel and the Deputies Chief Counsel to ensure that Standards they support both the goals of the MSOP and overall management goals of Chief Counsel. The Associate Chief Counsel or Division Counsel Plans also propose the standards by which performance of the goals will be measured. (

) The performance measures and standards are documented in a formal EPA that is signed by the Deputies Chief Counsel and the respective Associate Chief Counsel or Division Counsel. Each Associate Chief Counsel and Counsel is accountable for the accomplishment of the objectives in their mance plan and for the business results. (
) Each Associate Chief Counsel and Division Counsel is responsible for that their goals are incorporated into the performance plans of their subordi- of Associate nate SES and Grade
managers, positions, and organizations. Counsel or Counsel Goals (

) Assessments are written at the middle and end of the fiscal year by Chief Counsel and Division Counsel to document their performance in Chief Counsel plishing EPA objectives. The final appraisals, performed by the Deputies Division Counsel Counsel, rely on the Associate Chief Counsel and Division Counsel SES as- Assessments sessments. These are supplemented by statistics gathered by the Planning and Management Division. (

) The Planning and Management Division, under the direction of the Associate Chief Counsel (Finance and Management) assists the goal-writing process of the Planning and drafting EPAs based on guidance from new directives and priorities Division by the Chief Counsel. It distributes drafts, collates comments, and provides staff support at executive meetings until the objectives are finalized. The Planning and Management Division also helps construct quantifiable and surable goals and collects and analyzes statistical data to assist in the self- assessment process.
30.1 Office of Chief Counsel Mission Statement

Each Associate Chief Counsel and Division Counsel is responsible for ensuring that their goals are incorporated into the performance plans of their subordi- nate SES and Grade 15 managers, positions, and organizations.
The Planning and Management Division, under the direction of the Associate Chief Counsel (Finance and Management) assists the goal

writing process by drafting EPAs based on guidance from new directives and priorities established by the Chief Counsel. It distributes drafts, collates comments, and provides staff support at executive meetings until the objectives are finalized. The Planning and Management Division also helps construct quantifiable and mea
surable goals and collects and analyzes statistical data to assist in the self
assessment process.
